clinical_study.brief_title: Cigarette Smoke and Susceptibility to Influenza Infection
clinical_study.official_title: Cigarette Smoke and Susceptibility to Influenza Infection

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: This study will be a descriptive comparison of the effects of live attenuated influenza virus (FluMist) on nasal inflammation and oxidative stress in healthy young adults who are not exposed to smoke vs smokers. It is hypothesized that passive exposure to second-hand smoke (SHS) results in increased susceptibility to the effects of influenza virus in nasal epithelium in humans and that these effects are mediated by SHS-induced oxidative stress

detailed_description.textblock: Epidemiologic evidence supports a significant relationship between passive cigarette smoke exposure and increased risk for viral respiratory illnesses. Published and preliminary data suggest that airborne pollutants including tobacco smoke increase susceptibility of respiratory epithelium to infection with influenza A and that this effect is at least partially mediated by oxidative stress. However, no studies have specifically looked at the interaction between smoking and the effects of influenza virus in human volunteers.

primary_outcome.measure: Nasal responses of healthy adult volunteers not routinely exposed to SHS vs responses of smokers, to live attenuated influenza virus.

secondary_outcome.measure: Compare replication of live attenuated influenza virus (LAIV) in nasal epithelium of seronegative healthy adult volunteers not routinely exposed to SHS vs. smokers.
In the setting of LAIV infection, compare markers of oxidant stress and mucosal inflammation in nasal epithelium of healthy adult volunteers not routinely exposed to SHS vs. smokers

biospec_descr.textblock: nasal lavage fluid, urine, blood, nasal epithelial tissue from subjects who consent to have excess samples stored in our repository

1. smokers
2. nonsmokers who are NOT exposed to SHS
